title-group.article-title: Book Review: Carl Schmitt (trans. and ed. Timothy Nunan): Writings on War

article-meta.product: Writings on War. By SchmittCarl . Translated and edited by NunanTimothy . Cambridge: Polity, 2011. Pp. + . £17.99.

body.p: This volume comprises a well-considered introduction and three texts, originally published in German. Die Wendung zum diskriminerenden Kriegsbegriff (Turn to the Discriminating Concept of War, 1937), Völkerrechtliche Grossraumordnung mit Interventionsverbot für raumfremde Mächte, Ein Beitrag zum Reichsbegriff im Völkerrecht (The Grossraum Order of International Law with a Ban on Intervention for Spatially Foreign Powers: A Contribution to the Concept of Reich in International Law, 1939−41) and Das internationalrechtliche Verbrechenden Angriffskrieges und der Grundsatz ‘Nullum crimen, nulla poena sine lege’ (The International Crime of the War of Aggression and the Principle ‘Nullum crimen, nulla poena sine lege’, 1945).

As such, these works speak to interest in the work of Carl Schmitt (1888−1985), a prominent German political theorist who was a major critic of the jurisprudence of the liberal international order, and notably of the system of the Peace of Versailles and the Nuremberg trials. Schmitt is scarcely a neutral figure. In 1933, an opportune moment, he joined the Nazi Party and was promoted to a chair of law in Berlin. He was also president of the Union of National Socialist Jurists. For this reviewer, this background provides the context within which to view Schmitt’s criticism of the League, liberal notions of human rights, and the USA. Schmitt argued that the USA, in practice, dominated the western hemisphere, and that Germany should do the same in Europe. Schmitt of course was not responsible for Nazi policy and criminality, and I have written elsewhere on the geopoliticism of Karl Haushofer from this perspective. However, in light of his politics, I find it difficult to take Schmitt’s commentary seriously. His works do not deserve the undoubted scholarship of this edition and I found it an uncomfortable work.
